content: Set up your work area. Choose a well-ventilated space to paint the cornhole boards to prevent the buildup of paint fumes. Paint the boards outside or use an indoor room that has windows or doors you can open. Lay down drop cloths on a flat work surface to prevent the paint from making a mess. For example, if you work in your garage, keep the garage door open and lay drop cloths directly on the garage floor or a work bench. Fill any holes with wood filler . Check your cornhole boards for small holes or knots in the wood. Dip a putty knife into a container of wood filler so you have just a little bit on the end. Push the putty knife against the holes to fill them with the wood filler. Run the putty knife over the wood to smooth out the filler. Let the wood filler dry according to the manufacturer's instructions. [1] Most manufacturers recommend letting the filler dry for about 8 hours. Smooth the boards using sandpaper . Choose a medium grit piece of sandpaper or sanding block with a range of 60 to 100. Rub it over the plain boards to smooth over any bumps or dried wood filler. Sanding the boards will improve the surface of the boards so the primer and paint go on easier. [2] If you prefer, you can use an electric sander to smooth the boards down. Wipe off the boards with a smooth cloth. Run a clean cloth or rag under clean water and wring it out. Rub the damp cloth over the boards to remove any dust from sanding the boards. Let the boards dry completely before you prime them. Apply a primer to the boards. Choose a white oil-based primer to use on the cornhole boards. Open the primer and use a paint stirrer to briefly mix the primer. Dip your brush into the primer or pour some into a paint tray so you can use a roller. Use the brush or roller to apply a thin layer of primer over both cornhole boards. Let the primer dry for at least 1 hour or according to the manufacturer's instructions. [3] Oil-based primer works best with wood because it will penetrate deep into the wood and dry harder than water-based primers. Draw the pattern on the boards. If you're creating a detailed pattern or design, take a pencil and draw the design directly on the primed boards. This will give you an outline for painting the boards. [4] If you're making geometric designs (such as angles that point toward the hole) use a ruler or yardstick to draw straight lines. Choose a paint for the cornhole boards. Decide how glossy you want the painted boards to be. For a slight shine, choose a semigloss paint. For very shiny boards, pick a high gloss paint. Determine if you want to paint the boards a single color or if you want to paint each of them different colors. For example, you might paint 1 of the boards red and the other board blue. For detailed boards, use different colors or hues on each board. Use a brush or roller to apply a layer of paint to the boards. Open the paint and use a paint stirrer to combine the pigment and binders in the paint. Either dip a paintbrush into the paint can and wipe the excess on the rim of the can or pour the paint into a paint tray. Dip a roller into the tray and roll it back a few times to load the roller with paint. Brush or roll a thin layer of paint evenly over the board. Consider using spray paint. If you dislike painting or want to quickly get an even layer of paint on the boards, buy spray paint. Wear a face mask when using the spray paint so you don't breathe in the fumes. Spray the paint slowly and evenly so it doesn't pool on the boards. [5] To ensure that overspray from the spray paint won't get on any surrounding items, move things away from your work space and lay a drop cloth over the entire area. Dry the boards for at least 2 hours before applying another coat of paint. Follow the manufacturer's drying instructions or wait at least 2 hours before you apply another coat of paint. You'll probably need to paint a total of 3 to 5 coats of paint, waiting the full 2 hours between each coat of paint. Darker colors of paint or higher quality paint will need fewer coats of paint. Add extra colors or details. If you drew a design on the cornhole board, dip your paintbrush into another color of paint and paint along the design. For a cornhole board set that will really stand out, consider painting each board different colors (such as the colors of your favorite sports teams). Use painter's tape to create crisp edges or lines. Consider laying down painter's tape if you want to paint the edges a different color or just want to paint straight lines across the boards. The painter's tape can keep the paint from one section from bleeding into the next area on the board. Painter's tape is designed to peel off easily without removing the paint underneath it. Use a stencil to make designs on the board. If you'd like to make a complicated design (such as one with lots of swirls or small curves) use a stencil to get the high level of detail. Lay the stencil on the cornhole board and tape it down with a few pieces of painter's tape. Paint or spray paint over the stencil and then lift the stencil away. Let the design dry completely. [6] Apply decals or stickers. If you don't want to paint special designs by hand, but you want to make the boards look unique, place decals or stickers on them. To apply most decals or stickers, remove the backing and lay them on the painted boards. Rub over the decals or stickers to remove any air bubbles. [7] Include lettering on the boards . If you'd like paint letters or words on the boards, decide if you want to paint them by hand or use a stencil. To paint them by hand, draw a light guideline with a ruler to ensure that you paint the letters straight. If you'd rather not freehand the letters, lay down a stencil and paint over the letters you need. You could also apply letter decals to make your word. [8] Have a variety of brush sizes around so you can make the letters different sizes, if necessary.

<p>If you love playing cornhole but don't want to buy an expensive pair of boards, make and paint your own. Once you've assembled the basic wooden boards, prepare the wood by filling, sanding, and priming them. Determine how glossy you want the boards to be and then use a brush or roller to apply the paint. Always let the boards dry completely before adding coats of paint. Embellish your cornhole boards with designs, decals, or stickers.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Sanding_and_Priming_the_Boards_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Sanding_and_Priming_the_Boards">Sanding and Priming the Boards</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-1.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-1.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3e/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-1.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-1.jpg" height="546" id="img_d8df92d755" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d8df92d755')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3e/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-1.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-1.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Set up your work area.</b> Choose a well-ventilated space to paint the cornhole boards to prevent the buildup of paint fumes. Paint the boards outside or use an indoor room that has windows or doors you can open. Lay down drop cloths on a flat work surface to prevent the paint from making a mess.

<ul>
<li>For example, if you work in your garage, keep the garage door open and lay drop cloths directly on the garage floor or a work bench.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ec/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-2.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_9d1a1e1012" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9d1a1e1012')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ec/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-2.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Use-a-Wood-Filler" title="Use a Wood Filler">Fill any holes with wood filler</a>.</b> Check your cornhole boards for small holes or knots in the wood. Dip a putty knife into a container of wood filler so you have just a little bit on the end. Push the putty knife against the holes to fill them with the wood filler. Run the putty knife over the wood to smooth out the filler. Let the wood filler dry according to the manufacturer's instructions.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Most manufacturers recommend letting the filler dry for about 8 hours.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-3.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_5e74dbb1c5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5e74dbb1c5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-3.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Smooth the boards <a href="/Use-Sandpaper" title="Use Sandpaper">using sandpaper</a>.</b> Choose a medium grit piece of sandpaper or sanding block with a range of 60 to 100. Rub it over the plain boards to smooth over any bumps or dried wood filler. Sanding the boards will improve the surface of the boards so the primer and paint go on easier.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If you prefer, you can use an electric sander to smooth the boards down.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-4.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_89c2e9fb5c" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_89c2e9fb5c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-4.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Wipe off the boards with a smooth cloth.</b> Run a clean cloth or rag under clean water and wring it out. Rub the damp cloth over the boards to remove any dust from sanding the boards. Let the boards dry completely before you prime them.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-5.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_45ff89e22e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_45ff89e22e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-5.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Apply a primer to the boards.</b> Choose a white oil-based primer to use on the cornhole boards. Open the primer and use a paint stirrer to briefly mix the primer. Dip your brush into the primer or pour some into a paint tray so you can use a roller. Use the brush or roller to apply a thin layer of primer over both cornhole boards. Let the primer dry for at least 1 hour or according to the manufacturer's instructions.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Oil-based primer works best with wood because it will penetrate deep into the wood and dry harder than water-based primers.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Painting_Base_Layers_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Painting_Base_Layers">Painting Base Layers</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-6.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-6.jpg" height="546" id="img_7d207d694e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7d207d694e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-6.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Draw the pattern on the boards.</b> If you're creating a detailed pattern or design, take a pencil and draw the design directly on the primed boards. This will give you an outline for painting the boards.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If you're making geometric designs (such as angles that point toward the hole) use a ruler or yardstick to draw straight lines.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-7.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-7.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/ff/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-7.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-7.jpg" height="546" id="img_9b5a8bbcd3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9b5a8bbcd3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/ff/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-7.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-7.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Choose a paint for the cornhole boards.</b> Decide how glossy you want the painted boards to be. For a slight shine, choose a semigloss paint. For very shiny boards, pick a high gloss paint. Determine if you want to paint the boards a single color or if you want to paint each of them different colors.

<ul>
<li>For example, you might paint 1 of the boards red and the other board blue. For detailed boards, use different colors or hues on each board.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-8.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-8.jpg" height="546" id="img_e5a67cd80a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e5a67cd80a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-8.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use a brush or roller to apply a layer of paint to the boards.</b> Open the paint and use a paint stirrer to combine the pigment and binders in the paint. Either dip a paintbrush into the paint can and wipe the excess on the rim of the can or pour the paint into a paint tray. Dip a roller into the tray and roll it back a few times to load the roller with paint. Brush or roll a thin layer of paint evenly over the board.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-9.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_a2592c3f85" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a2592c3f85')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-9.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider using spray paint.</b> If you dislike painting or want to quickly get an even layer of paint on the boards, buy spray paint. Wear a face mask when using the spray paint so you don't breathe in the fumes. Spray the paint slowly and evenly so it doesn't pool on the boards.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>To ensure that overspray from the spray paint won't get on any surrounding items, move things away from your work space and lay a drop cloth over the entire area.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/81/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-10.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-10.jpg" height="546" id="img_79605d83f0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_79605d83f0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/81/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-10.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Dry the boards for at least 2 hours before applying another coat of paint.</b> Follow the manufacturer's drying instructions or wait at least 2 hours before you apply another coat of paint. You'll probably need to paint a total of 3 to 5 coats of paint, waiting the full 2 hours between each coat of paint.

<ul>
<li>Darker colors of paint or higher quality paint will need fewer coats of paint.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Adding_Embellishments_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Adding_Embellishments">Adding Embellishments</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/72/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-11.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_3d032eb54e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3d032eb54e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/72/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-11.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Add extra colors or details.</b> If you drew a design on the cornhole board, dip your paintbrush into another color of paint and paint along the design. For a cornhole board set that will really stand out, consider painting each board different colors (such as the colors of your favorite sports teams).

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-12.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_b91338a02f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b91338a02f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-12.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use painter's tape to create crisp edges or lines.</b> Consider laying down painter's tape if you want to paint the edges a different color or just want to paint straight lines across the boards. The painter's tape can keep the paint from one section from bleeding into the next area on the board.

<ul>
<li>Painter's tape is designed to peel off easily without removing the paint underneath it.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-13.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-13.jpg" height="546" id="img_f2ad614e60" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f2ad614e60')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-13.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use a stencil to make designs on the board.</b> If you'd like to make a complicated design (such as one with lots of swirls or small curves) use a stencil to get the high level of detail. Lay the stencil on the cornhole board and tape it down with a few pieces of painter's tape. Paint or spray paint over the stencil and then lift the stencil away. Let the design dry completely.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-14.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_f2fbd2906a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f2fbd2906a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-14.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Apply decals or stickers.</b> If you don't want to paint special designs by hand, but you want to make the boards look unique, place decals or stickers on them. To apply most decals or stickers, remove the backing and lay them on the painted boards. Rub over the decals or stickers to remove any air bubbles.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=9529695" href="#/Image:Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-15.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-15.jpg" height="546" id="img_d81d1b50d1" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d81d1b50d1')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Paint Cornhole Boards Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-15.jpg/aid9529695-v4-728px-Paint-Cornhole-Boards-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb"><a href="/Paint-Letters-on-Wood" title="Paint Letters on Wood">Include lettering on the boards</a>.</b> If you'd like paint letters or words on the boards, decide if you want to paint them by hand or use a stencil. To paint them by hand, draw a light guideline with a ruler to ensure that you paint the letters straight. If you'd rather not freehand the letters, lay down a stencil and paint over the letters you need. You could also apply letter decals to make your word.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Have a variety of brush sizes around so you can make the letters different sizes, if necessary.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>

<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>To keep your cornhole boards looking great, avoid storing them outside. If you have to keep them outdoors, use an exterior paint on the boards.</li>
</ul>

</div>

    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",

        "width": 1200,
        "height": 900
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",

    "aggregateRating": {
        "@type": "AggregateRating",

        "ratingValue": 79
    },
    "datePublished": "2017-11-26",
    "dateModified": "2019-03-29",
    "publisher": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",

        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Sanding and Priming the Boards",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Set up your work area. Choose a well-ventilated space to paint the cornhole boards to prevent the buildup of paint fumes. Paint the boards outside or use an indoor room that has windows or doors you can open. Lay down drop cloths on a flat work surface to prevent the paint from making a mess.\n\nFor example, if you work in your garage, keep the garage door open and lay drop cloths directly on the garage floor or a work bench."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Fill any holes with wood filler. Check your cornhole boards for small holes or knots in the wood. Dip a putty knife into a container of wood filler so you have just a little bit on the end. Push the putty knife against the holes to fill them with the wood filler. Run the putty knife over the wood to smooth out the filler. Let the wood filler dry according to the manufacturer's instructions.[1]\nMost manufacturers recommend letting the filler dry for about 8 hours."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Smooth the boards using sandpaper. Choose a medium grit piece of sandpaper or sanding block with a range of 60 to 100. Rub it over the plain boards to smooth over any bumps or dried wood filler. Sanding the boards will improve the surface of the boards so the primer and paint go on easier.[2]\nIf you prefer, you can use an electric sander to smooth the boards down."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Wipe off the boards with a smooth cloth. Run a clean cloth or rag under clean water and wring it out. Rub the damp cloth over the boards to remove any dust from sanding the boards. Let the boards dry completely before you prime them."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Apply a primer to the boards. Choose a white oil-based primer to use on the cornhole boards. Open the primer and use a paint stirrer to briefly mix the primer. Dip your brush into the primer or pour some into a paint tray so you can use a roller. Use the brush or roller to apply a thin layer of primer over both cornhole boards. Let the primer dry for at least 1 hour or according to the manufacturer's instructions.[3]\nOil-based primer works best with wood because it will penetrate deep into the wood and dry harder than water-based primers."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Painting Base Layers",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Draw the pattern on the boards. If you're creating a detailed pattern or design, take a pencil and draw the design directly on the primed boards. This will give you an outline for painting the boards.[4]\nIf you're making geometric designs (such as angles that point toward the hole) use a ruler or yardstick to draw straight lines."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Choose a paint for the cornhole boards. Decide how glossy you want the painted boards to be. For a slight shine, choose a semigloss paint. For very shiny boards, pick a high gloss paint. Determine if you want to paint the boards a single color or if you want to paint each of them different colors.\n\nFor example, you might paint 1 of the boards red and the other board blue. For detailed boards, use different colors or hues on each board."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Use a brush or roller to apply a layer of paint to the boards. Open the paint and use a paint stirrer to combine the pigment and binders in the paint. Either dip a paintbrush into the paint can and wipe the excess on the rim of the can or pour the paint into a paint tray. Dip a roller into the tray and roll it back a few times to load the roller with paint. Brush or roll a thin layer of paint evenly over the board."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Consider using spray paint. If you dislike painting or want to quickly get an even layer of paint on the boards, buy spray paint. Wear a face mask when using the spray paint so you don't breathe in the fumes. Spray the paint slowly and evenly so it doesn't pool on the boards.[5]\nTo ensure that overspray from the spray paint won't get on any surrounding items, move things away from your work space and lay a drop cloth over the entire area."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Dry the boards for at least 2 hours before applying another coat of paint. Follow the manufacturer's drying instructions or wait at least 2 hours before you apply another coat of paint. You'll probably need to paint a total of 3 to 5 coats of paint, waiting the full 2 hours between each coat of paint.\n\nDarker colors of paint or higher quality paint will need fewer coats of paint."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Adding Embellishments",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",

title: How to Paint Cornhole Boards
content_html:
Set up your work area. Choose a well-ventilated space to paint the cornhole boards to prevent the buildup of paint fumes. Paint the boards outside or use an indoor room that has windows or doors you can open. Lay down drop cloths on a flat work surface to prevent the paint from making a mess.
  • For example, if you work in your garage, keep the garage door open and lay drop cloths directly on the garage floor or a work bench.
Fill any holes with wood filler. Check your cornhole boards for small holes or knots in the wood. Dip a putty knife into a container of wood filler so you have just a little bit on the end. Push the putty knife against the holes to fill them with the wood filler. Run the putty knife over the wood to smooth out the filler. Let the wood filler dry according to the manufacturer's instructions.[1]
  • Most manufacturers recommend letting the filler dry for about 8 hours.
Smooth the boards using sandpaper. Choose a medium grit piece of sandpaper or sanding block with a range of 60 to 100. Rub it over the plain boards to smooth over any bumps or dried wood filler. Sanding the boards will improve the surface of the boards so the primer and paint go on easier.[2]
  • If you prefer, you can use an electric sander to smooth the boards down.
Wipe off the boards with a smooth cloth. Run a clean cloth or rag under clean water and wring it out. Rub the damp cloth over the boards to remove any dust from sanding the boards. Let the boards dry completely before you prime them.
Apply a primer to the boards. Choose a white oil-based primer to use on the cornhole boards. Open the primer and use a paint stirrer to briefly mix the primer. Dip your brush into the primer or pour some into a paint tray so you can use a roller. Use the brush or roller to apply a thin layer of primer over both cornhole boards. Let the primer dry for at least 1 hour or according to the manufacturer's instructions.[3]
  • Oil-based primer works best with wood because it will penetrate deep into the wood and dry harder than water-based primers.
Draw the pattern on the boards. If you're creating a detailed pattern or design, take a pencil and draw the design directly on the primed boards. This will give you an outline for painting the boards.[4]
  • If you're making geometric designs (such as angles that point toward the hole) use a ruler or yardstick to draw straight lines.
Choose a paint for the cornhole boards. Decide how glossy you want the painted boards to be. For a slight shine, choose a semigloss paint. For very shiny boards, pick a high gloss paint. Determine if you want to paint the boards a single color or if you want to paint each of them different colors.
  • For example, you might paint 1 of the boards red and the other board blue. For detailed boards, use different colors or hues on each board.
Use a brush or roller to apply a layer of paint to the boards. Open the paint and use a paint stirrer to combine the pigment and binders in the paint. Either dip a paintbrush into the paint can and wipe the excess on the rim of the can or pour the paint into a paint tray. Dip a roller into the tray and roll it back a few times to load the roller with paint. Brush or roll a thin layer of paint evenly over the board.
Consider using spray paint. If you dislike painting or want to quickly get an even layer of paint on the boards, buy spray paint. Wear a face mask when using the spray paint so you don't breathe in the fumes. Spray the paint slowly and evenly so it doesn't pool on the boards.[5]
  • To ensure that overspray from the spray paint won't get on any surrounding items, move things away from your work space and lay a drop cloth over the entire area.
Dry the boards for at least 2 hours before applying another coat of paint. Follow the manufacturer's drying instructions or wait at least 2 hours before you apply another coat of paint. You'll probably need to paint a total of 3 to 5 coats of paint, waiting the full 2 hours between each coat of paint.
  • Darker colors of paint or higher quality paint will need fewer coats of paint.
Add extra colors or details. If you drew a design on the cornhole board, dip your paintbrush into another color of paint and paint along the design. For a cornhole board set that will really stand out, consider painting each board different colors (such as the colors of your favorite sports teams).
Use painter's tape to create crisp edges or lines. Consider laying down painter's tape if you want to paint the edges a different color or just want to paint straight lines across the boards. The painter's tape can keep the paint from one section from bleeding into the next area on the board.
  • Painter's tape is designed to peel off easily without removing the paint underneath it.
Use a stencil to make designs on the board. If you'd like to make a complicated design (such as one with lots of swirls or small curves) use a stencil to get the high level of detail. Lay the stencil on the cornhole board and tape it down with a few pieces of painter's tape. Paint or spray paint over the stencil and then lift the stencil away. Let the design dry completely.[6]
Apply decals or stickers. If you don't want to paint special designs by hand, but you want to make the boards look unique, place decals or stickers on them. To apply most decals or stickers, remove the backing and lay them on the painted boards. Rub over the decals or stickers to remove any air bubbles.[7]
Include lettering on the boards. If you'd like paint letters or words on the boards, decide if you want to paint them by hand or use a stencil. To paint them by hand, draw a light guideline with a ruler to ensure that you paint the letters straight. If you'd rather not freehand the letters, lay down a stencil and paint over the letters you need. You could also apply letter decals to make your word.[8]
  • Have a variety of brush sizes around so you can make the letters different sizes, if necessary.
